positive.review: 39 minutes of clicking, collecting, and pretending to be a lord. Winter came, I left
Game of Thrones Donate is Coming
This game is a good start for beginners.
Very Addictive.
YES!!!!
39 minutes of clicking, collecting, and pretending to be a lord. Winter came, I left

I love this game. I don't care about the "pay to win" parts. If you take it seriously it can get boring overtime.
Pay for fun. Don't waste your resources all in one go - it DOES take time to gain the resources needed to upgrade things.

Yes, the game is a 'Pay to Win' game, but it's still stands as a 'Free to Play" game. At the time of this review I am close to 300 Million power alone, and with years of playing ... etc. With very minimal bought, the game daily rewards builds up the more you play, as a free to play game, the more daily rewards and some good RNG at times, you can casually play and have truces on daily, to prevent loss of resources/troops. Starting out is tough, but reaching near high mid level, and know-how to gain the daily rewards/events, it gets easier.

The game does hit roadblocks as limits for certain actions at certain levels. However, it's a casual game, most daily rewards can be done within under an hour. Longer missions such as unlocking advanced research takes longer though, when it gets to be above a month per upgrade or more ... It gets to be even more casual.

But that's why daily rewards and missions, and events help too in speeding up the process. When there is nothing left to do, it does leave a wanting more type of feeling. But free to play, as a pay to win game has limits, usually the players that like the game they play, are more inclined to spend on the game.

From the Start to now, starting out is the toughest part, it's mostly saving diamonds for truces, collecting commanders, and using commanders in Weirwood Tree to advance more ... And the hard part is maintaining a 1K diamonds a day on a 'Free to Play' basis. The training grounds does give diamonds every 3 hours, however, advanced commanders usually do better. Focusing on getting a healer, such as Jeane or Sansa Stark, Simon BlackMyre etc. can provide helpful healing in storyline battles to advance and gain more.

Collecting resources will be a large part as well, on a free to play basis, saving gold dragons for your upgrades for research, troops, will be the most part of the journey. Finding a low populated world can help 'farm' resources and do daily resource collecting possibly easier. But there are most likely others around the same level or higher as you and will attack and vice versa, and it becomes a bit tougher when truces aren't available.

One way to gain diamonds monthly at an increased rate is the Iron Bank in your city. The iron bank has a wait time but it is worth upgrading to increase output. For the most part once truces can be maintained daily/weekly, it goes more smoothly at competing and preparing for events for larger rewards. it's a farming game (building, creating troops, collecting resources etc.) but it has it's PVP side too, like battles and during some events, like Kingdom vs Kingdom, and All out War etc. it gets more active.

Overall, it stays true to the likeness of Game of Thrones HBO show, and it is recommended to play and if this isn't your type of game, check out Game of Thrones: Kingsroad, it's also free to play.
Game of Thrones Donate is Coming
This game is a good start for beginners.
loe thsi show and thsi game is fun
Very Addictive.
simple and fun
YES!!!!

For the most part once truces can be maintained daily/weekly, it goes more smoothly at competing and preparing for events for larger rewards. it's a farming game (building, creating troops, collecting resources etc.) but it has it's PVP side too, like battles and during some events, like Kingdom vs Kingdom, and All out War etc. it gets more active.

Overall, it stays true to the likeness of Game of Thrones HBO show, and it is recommended to play and if this isn't your type of game, check out Game of Thrones: Kingsroad, it's also free to play.

39 minutes of clicking, collecting, and pretending to be a lord. Winter came, I left

I love this game. I don't care about the "pay to win" parts. If you take it seriously it can get boring overtime.
Pay for fun. Don't waste your resources all in one go - it DOES take time to gain the resources needed to upgrade things.

Yes, the game is a 'Pay to Win' game, but it's still stands as a 'Free to Play" game. At the time of this review I am close to 300 Million power alone, and with years of playing ... etc. With very minimal bought, the game daily rewards builds up the more you play, as a free to play game, the more daily rewards and some good RNG at times, you can casually play and have truces on daily, to prevent loss of resources/troops. Starting out is tough, but reaching near high mid level, and know-how to gain the daily rewards/events, it gets easier.

The game does hit roadblocks as limits for certain actions at certain levels. However, it's a casual game, most daily rewards can be done within under an hour. Longer missions such as unlocking advanced research takes longer though, when it gets to be above a month per upgrade or more ... It gets to be even more casual.

But that's why daily rewards and missions, and events help too in speeding up the process. When there is nothing left to do, it does leave a wanting more type of feeling. But free to play, as a pay to win game has limits, usually the players that like the game they play, are more inclined to spend on the game.

From the Start to now, starting out is the toughest part, it's mostly saving diamonds for truces, collecting commanders, and using commanders in Weirwood Tree to advance more ... And the hard part is maintaining a 1K diamonds a day on a 'Free to Play' basis. The training grounds does give diamonds every 3 hours, however, advanced commanders usually do better. Focusing on getting a healer, such as Jeane or Sansa Stark, Simon BlackMyre etc. can provide helpful healing in storyline battles to advance and gain more.

Collecting resources will be a large part as well, on a free to play basis, saving gold dragons for your upgrades for research, troops, will be the most part of the journey. Finding a low populated world can help 'farm' resources and do daily resource collecting possibly easier. But there are most likely others around the same level or higher as you and will attack and vice versa, and it becomes a bit tougher when truces aren't available.

One way to gain diamonds monthly at an increased rate is the Iron Bank in your city. The iron bank has a wait time but it is worth upgrading to increase output. For the most part once truces can be maintained daily/weekly, it goes more smoothly at competing and preparing for events for larger rewards. it's a farming game (building, creating troops, collecting resources etc.) but it has it's PVP side too, like battles and during some events, like Kingdom vs Kingdom, and All out War etc. it gets more active.

Overall, it stays true to the likeness of Game of Thrones HBO show, and it is recommended to play and if this isn't your type of game, check out Game of Thrones: Kingsroad, it's also free to play.

Very Addictive.

negative.review: the whole game revolves around how much money you spend theres no skill or expertise involved.You can study the best ways to build your account and a player who spends a lot with no knowledge will still annialate you.New servers are introduced once the money dries up from the previous one and youll always get at least one who spends and dominates lol

This game looks great on the surface—the graphics are polished and the whole Game of Thrones theme definitely pulls you in at first. Unfortunately, like many similar base-building war games, the shine fades quickly once you realize how the system is set up.

The biggest issue: it’s very pay-to-win. There’s no real effort to separate whales from casual players. Once your protection runs out, the big spenders will swoop in and wipe you out. It’s not just frustrating—it makes progression feel pointless unless you’re ready to drop a serious amount of cash.

Gameplay itself is nothing new if you’ve played other builder/war games. It feels like the GoT branding is more of a skin laid over the same old mechanics: build, upgrade, wait, repeat. Events and alliances help a little, but they’re often just more ways to encourage spending.

To be fair, there are some positives: the interface is clean, the battles look decent, and if you’re a hardcore GoT fan, you’ll probably enjoy seeing the familiar characters and locations. But none of that makes up for the imbalance and constant pressure to spend.

Bottom line: unless they make the playing field more fair—like separating paying players from casual ones—I can’t recommend it. The game could be fun, but right now it’s designed to drain your wallet more than entertain.

its like phone app games you have to pump money in to get any were trying to level my dragon you need shadow essence which you don't get for free anymore when you scout so upgrading my dragon will cost me $200 at least.

This is terrible game cause it looks like a mobile game, definitely not for pc; totally for mobile. If playing this game on mobile phone, its good, go for it. But never try it even on ur pc. Such a waste of time. Mobile in, PC out. (No idea there's exist for mobile)

the whole game revolves around how much money you spend theres no skill or expertise involved.You can study the best ways to build your account and a player who spends a lot with no knowledge will still annialate you.New servers are introduced once the money dries up from the previous one and youll always get at least one who spends and dominates lol

To be fair, there are some positives: the interface is clean, the battles look decent, and if you’re a hardcore GoT fan, you’ll probably enjoy seeing the familiar characters and locations. But none of that makes up for the imbalance and constant pressure to spend.

Bottom line: unless they make the playing field more fair—like separating paying players from casual ones—I can’t recommend it. The game could be fun, but right now it’s designed to drain your wallet more than entertain.

its like phone app games you have to pump money in to get any were trying to level my dragon you need shadow essence which you don't get for free anymore when you scout so upgrading my dragon will cost me $200 at least.

This is terrible game cause it looks like a mobile game, definitely not for pc; totally for mobile. If playing this game on mobile phone, its good, go for it. But never try it even on ur pc. Such a waste of time. Mobile in, PC out. (No idea there's exist for mobile)

the whole game revolves around how much money you spend theres no skill or expertise involved.You can study the best ways to build your account and a player who spends a lot with no knowledge will still annialate you.New servers are introduced once the money dries up from the previous one and youll always get at least one who spends and dominates lol

This game looks great on the surface—the graphics are polished and the whole Game of Thrones theme definitely pulls you in at first. Unfortunately, like many similar base-building war games, the shine fades quickly once you realize how the system is set up.

The biggest issue: it’s very pay-to-win. There’s no real effort to separate whales from casual players. Once your protection runs out, the big spenders will swoop in and wipe you out. It’s not just frustrating—it makes progression feel pointless unless you’re ready to drop a serious amount of cash.

Gameplay itself is nothing new if you’ve played other builder/war games. It feels like the GoT branding is more of a skin laid over the same old mechanics: build, upgrade, wait, repeat. Events and alliances help a little, but they’re often just more ways to encourage spending.

To be fair, there are some positives: the interface is clean, the battles look decent, and if you’re a hardcore GoT fan, you’ll probably enjoy seeing the familiar characters and locations. But none of that makes up for the imbalance and constant pressure to spend.

Bottom line: unless they make the playing field more fair—like separating paying players from casual ones—I can’t recommend it. The game could be fun, but right now it’s designed to drain your wallet more than entertain.
